themes.name: Refusing to accept illness as permanent and relentless hope for improvement
themes.description: This theme centers on participants' ongoing belief that recovery is possible, even after decades of severe illness and setbacks. Despite medical advice to accept limitations, participants described a stubborn optimism and refusal to let illness define their future, expressing persistent hope and denial of permanence. This mindset was an active driver of their behaviors, fueling efforts to seek improvement and new approaches, as captured in repeated statements about never giving up and always seeing possibility.

themes.name: Struggling to set boundaries and achieve genuine rest despite ingrained habits
themes.description: Across the interviews, participants expressed ongoing difficulty with overexertion and deeply rooted people-pleasing patterns. Learning to establish boundaries was described as 'the hardest' ongoing challenge, manifesting in behaviors like letting calls go to voicemail and resisting compulsion to 'get things done.' Achieving real, restorative rest required conscious retraining and daily effort to fight habits of distraction and self-neglect, highlighting the exhaustion of constantly needing to prioritize self-care amid internal and external pressures.

themes.name: Facing emotional impacts of isolation and being misunderstood by others
themes.description: Participants described feeling isolated and emotionally stressed when misunderstood or judged by others, particularly those who minimized or dismissed the reality of ME/CFS. This lack of understanding led to frustration, anger, and a sense of being alone in their struggles. Family support provided solace, yet interactions with outsiders evoked emotional triggers and challenges in managing reactions to ignorance and skepticism about their illness, reinforcing the participant's sense of isolation and emotional strain.

themes.name: Experiencing identity change through listening to body and making lifestyle shifts
themes.description: This theme captures the transformation experienced by participants as they learned to listen to their body and identify personal triggers. Recovery involved significant lifestyle and identity changes, where participants became attuned to their bodily signals, prioritized their health, and accepted the necessity of ongoing adjustments. The theme reflects a journey of self-discovery, recognition that needs are valid, and movement away from past habits or denial, emphasizing self-awareness as a meaningful outcome.

themes.name: Difficulty accepting dependence and receiving help during severe illness
themes.description: During periods of acute unwellness, participants felt conflicted about their dependence on others for basic needs. While support from friends and family was indispensable, needing help evoked mixed feelings around vulnerability, loss of autonomy, and emotional discomfort. These experiences were described as necessary yet fraught, with participants expressing struggle to reconcile personal limits and the emotional weight of receiving care in times of incapacity.

themes.name: Initial skepticism and emotional resistance to new healing approaches and brain retraining
themes.description: Participants frequently encountered emotional and cognitive barriers when introduced to new therapeutic modalities, particularly psychological or neurological frameworks like brain retraining. Initial reactions included skepticism, resistance, and concern about the legitimacy of such approaches in contrast to biomedical explanations. However, engagement with these therapies sometimes led to improvement and hope as participants reconciled their doubts and found meaning in new paths to recovery.

codes.name: Feeling overwhelmed and scared by the diversity of symptoms experienced
codes.description: Participants express confusion, overwhelm, and fear when faced with the sudden or gradual onset of a wide array of symptoms associated with MECFS, such as fatigue, pain, memory issues, and sensitivities. The unpredictable combination and intensity of symptoms create distress and challenges in knowing how to respond or where to begin addressing their health concerns.
quotes: there can be such a crazy mix of symptoms coming at you...this onslaught of new symptoms can be overwhelming and confusing and scary

codes.name: Seeking reassurance and hope by comparing symptoms with others who have recovered
codes.description: Participants desire to compare their own symptoms against those of others who have recovered from MECFS as a way to gauge their prospects for recovery. quotes: i think the first reason that this is happening...people want to see if we're the same if my symptoms match your symptoms and i recovered then that means that there's good hope that you can recover

codes.name: Desire for a recovery approach personalised to own symptoms and circumstances
codes.description: Participants express the need for a recovery plan tailored to their unique experience, symptoms, starting point, and lifestyle. stay true to what's going to work for you...your whole makeup will be different

themes.name: Feeling like life is a miracle after years of suffering
themes.description: Participants describe life after recovery as living a miracle, full of childlike wonder and gratitude. This theme captures the sense of having a second chance at life, never wanting to become "a normal person who takes it for granted." The renewed appreciation for everyday experiences, described as enlivening and as "winning the race every day," highlights how surviving chronic illness profoundly shapes ongoing joy and perspective.

themes.name: Experiencing deep emotional separation from those without chronic illness
themes.description: This theme reflects the strong feelings of alienation and detachment participants have from friends and peers who haven’t experienced chronic illness. Complaints about ordinary stressors like work or exercise become emotional triggers, as participants struggle with people who take their health for granted. The lack of shared experience leads to difficulty relating and maintaining friendships, emphasizing the lingering emotional gap chronic illness constructs.

themes.name: Transforming self-worth from achievement to unconditional acceptance and humility
themes.description: Participants reveal a dramatic shift in self-identity after illness. Formerly anchored in professional achievement and productivity, identity becomes rooted in a deeper sense of worth and humility. The experience of accepting help, being valued regardless of accomplishments, and finding support from others emerges as crucial. Illness humbles participants and offers greater appreciation of human connection and intrinsic value.

themes.name: Recognizing and healing psychological and spiritual wounds as part of recovery
themes.description: Recovery from chronic illness encompasses more than physical healing. This theme captures the need for mind-body work, trauma healing, spiritual growth, and letting go of fear and control. Participants describe spiritual practices and prayer as transformative, giving meaning and depth to their journey. The process is described as surrendering, regaining faith, and integrating all aspects of self into lasting recovery.

themes.name: Enduring desperation driving radical lifestyle transformation for health
themes.description: Desperation is a pivotal emotional driver for change. Facing severe symptoms, participants become willing to endure drastic and difficult lifestyle modifications, including elimination diets, removal of environmental toxins, and adapting movement routines. The theme highlights the struggle, reliance on support, and how feeling “so desperate” finally makes the previously unthinkable possible for the chance to reclaim life.

themes.name: Finding freedom and relief after overcoming food addiction and cravings
themes.description: This theme focuses on participants’ intense battle with food addiction—especially sugar—and the profound liberation felt once food is no longer a source of struggle. Recovery brings an end to lifelong cravings, replacing desperation with a healthy relationship to food. Describing their path as “freedom,” participants value this transformation as one of their most meaningful outcomes, removing a persistent barrier to wellbeing.

themes.name: Embracing hope and inspiration from the stories of others who have recovered
themes.description: Seeing and hearing about others’ recovery is vital for participants’ motivation and belief in the possibility of wellness. This theme centers around the impact of recovery stories on resilience, the need to reject limiting medical prognoses, and the significance of “undeniable evidence” that people do get better. Participants cherish these stories as lifelines and fuel during the hardest moments.

themes.name: Accepting imperfection and normal fluctuations after chronic illness
themes.description: Participants grapple with anxiety over possible relapse, learning to distinguish normal discomforts from returning symptoms. This theme captures the process of recognizing imperfection in recovery—"getting better doesn't mean perfection"—and cultivating self-compassion. Comparing themselves to “normal healthy people” who have headaches or bad days, participants actively draw boundaries and remind themselves of what is common and expected.

themes.name: Rejecting quick fixes and symptom chasing in favor of holistic approaches
themes.description: Participants find that chasing individual symptoms with pills or supplements proves ineffective for long-term recovery. Instead, they discover the necessity of root-cause, holistic strategies tailored to personal needs. This theme articulates the futility of seeking universal solutions, with supplements only working based on specific blood work and genetic profiles, and highlights the wisdom gained from focusing on core healing.

themes.name: Encountering and responding to skepticism about illness and recovery
themes.description: Recovery brings challenges beyond healing, including doubts from others about the authenticity of illness and recovery. This theme encompasses participants’ experiences of skepticism, feeling attacked, and their choice to respond with confidence rather than defensiveness. The struggle to validate their stories and the importance of knowing their own truth become ongoing elements of the post-recovery journey.

themes.name: Experiencing profound loss, isolation, and grief after sudden chronic illness diagnosis
themes.description: Participants described overwhelming loss of independence and social connection after illness onset at a young age. Medical misunderstanding fueled despair as doctors dismissed their symptoms as mere depression. This period brought shock, emotional struggle, and deep grief, with feelings of being scared, alone, and disconnected from peers and normal life. The search for validation and a true diagnosis intensified emotional suffering and the sense of not being understood.

themes.name: Pursuing every possible avenue for healing amid desperation and fluctuating hope
themes.description: Desperation to recover drove participants to exhaustively pursue therapies, from acupuncture to reiki, colonic irrigation, and even overseas healers. This theme highlights the continual experimentation, sense of urgency, and willingness to try anything to escape suffering and find sustainable improvement, even when many attempts led to disappointment.

themes.name: Discovering emotional suppression, unresolved trauma, and the mind-body connection
themes.description: A turning point in recovery was the recognition that suppressed anger, avoidance of conflict, and unresolved trauma were linked to physical symptoms. codes.name: Fear of losing identity and sense of self during illness
codes.description: Participants expressed a deep fear of losing their personal identity due to the limitations and isolation imposed by CFS/ME and Long COVID. The illness fundamentally altered how they saw themselves, making them feel disconnected from the life and activities that had previously defined them.
quotes: ...I didn’t recognize myself anymore, I just felt like all I was was sick.
I was terrified I’d never get back to the person I was.

codes.name: Longing for validation and need to be believed about symptoms
codes.description: Participants strongly desired that medical professionals, family, and friends acknowledge their illness as real and serious. Not being believed led to feelings of loneliness, frustration, and emotional distress, as their symptoms were often dismissed or minimized.
quotes: Nobody really believed me when I said I couldn’t get out of bed...
It made me feel invisible, like my suffering wasn’t real to anyone except me.
I needed someone to just say, ‘I believe you.’

codes.name: Desire for hope and possibility of recovery
codes.description: Maintaining hope for improvement or recovery was central to participants’ emotional wellbeing. When hope felt possible, it gave motivation to try new treatments and persevere, while a lack of hope made symptoms feel unbearable and the future bleak.
quotes: What kept me going was the hope that I could get my life back.
I just needed to see someone who had recovered, to know it was possible.

codes.name: Searching for meaning and purpose despite illness
codes.description: Participants sought ways to rediscover a sense of meaning and purpose in life, even when severely ill. They described a struggle to find activities and connections that brought fulfillment, especially when previous sources of meaning were no longer possible.
quotes: I had to find something every day to look forward to, even if it was small.
...when I got sick, I lost my entire sense of purpose.

codes.name: Strong need for control and autonomy over health decisions
codes.description: Controlling their own treatment and recovery process was crucial for participants. They described frustration when excluded from medical decisions and desired to experiment with therapies and approaches that felt right for them, rather than passively following others’ plans.
quotes: It felt important just to decide what I wanted to try...
I hated not having control over my own health.

Illness acted as a catalyst for discovering self-worth, resilience, and new life directions.', quotes=['I am at this point where it’s like I’m grateful for the ways I’ve grown', 'Illness can be a gift...one of the things that led or fed into the symptoms...we have the chance to rebalance in ourselves', 'Turning self criticism into self compassion, learning to take more personal empowerment']), Code(slug='desire-to-help-community', name='Strong desire to help others through shared experience and support', description='Having recovered, the participant is motivated to provide hope, knowledge, and compassionate support to others with similar struggles by sharing their story, coaching, and teaching. They experience fulfillment and purpose by connecting and supporting their community.', quotes=['It really does feel like my calling...I want to do it', 'It’s amazing to see people not just recover but like learn and heal and grow', 'I am so grateful to people like yourself...for doing this'])]
codes=[Code(slug='gradual-loss-energy-motivation', name='Feeling a gradual loss of energy and motivation for activity', description='This code captures the participant’s experience of becoming unusually tired and losing the motivation to engage in activities they previously enjoyed. The shift from being very active to spending more time in bed highlights a new and distressing physical limitation.', quotes=["i typically am a very active person ... a phase ... started to get really tired and i didn't have the motivation to go out ...", 'just started to notice things like laying in bed ... not feeling the best']), Code(slug='doctor-dismissal-frustration', name='Frustration at doctors dismissing symptoms as nothing', description='This code describes the participant’s feelings of frustration and abandonment after multiple doctors found her blood work and vitals normal, yet she continued to experience serious symptoms. 'never really had that type of technique']), Code(slug='positive-affect-techniques-rapid-progress', name='Positive impact of new techniques with rapid progress', description='This code captures the participant’s sense of excitement and validation experienced after adopting new recovery tools such as brain retraining, noticing significant improvements in symptoms within weeks and eventually regaining full wellbeing in months.', quotes=['i started to see it maybe two weeks after ... it really changed within six months i was back to feeling fully well']), Code(slug='restored-physical-challenge-motivation', name='Motivation to physically challenge oneself again post-recovery', description='This code highlights the feeling of regaining motivation to participate in physically demanding activities post-recovery, culminating in running races and setting new goals, underpinned by a strengthened mindset.', quotes=['first ten k that i ran ... motivating me to get back out there and challenge my body ...', "now i'm training for a full marathon ... before i don't think i would have had the mental stamina to do that"]), Code(slug='growth-mindset-affiliations', name='Desiring to be around others with a growth mindset', description='This code encompasses the participant’s newfound eagerness to associate with people who strive to improve and challenge themselves, reflecting a personal transformation in social preferences connected to recovery.', quotes=['i am more eager to surround myself with people who have the growth mindset that they want to continue to challenge themselves and get better']), Code(slug='empowerment-language-shift', name='Shifting to empowering statements about progress and emotion', description='This code highlights the participant’s discovery of how specific language (such as journey-oriented affirmations) can enhance positivity and avoid feelings of being stuck, supporting emotional and psychological recovery.', quotes=["i also use a lot more of empowering statements ... instead you could say i am on my way to getting better and that's more of a journey rather than oh i'm stuck at this state of anxiety"]), Code(slug='importance-personal-support-program', name='Valuing personalized support and belief from program leaders', description='This code describes the participant’s appreciation for direct personal encouragement and communication from her recovery program leader, which fostered hope and perseverance, especially given the initial lack of support within medical settings.', quotes=["one of the best parts of this program is how personable jason is ... he'd send ... text messages randomly ... having someone who believes in you that much even though we were complete strangers"]), Code(slug='incomplete-recovery-tools-coping', name='Accepting incomplete recovery and relying on coping tools', description='This code notes the participant’s pragmatic acceptance that fatigue and anxiety may persist at times, but she now feels equipped to manage these challenges using the tools learned, marking a realistic outlook toward ongoing health.', quotes=["there's still some days where i do feel very tired but i have now these tools to fix that ... i can refocus and use these tools to pass it"]), Code(slug='desire-validation-peer-support', name='Desire for validation and connection with peers facing similar challenges', description='This code represents the participant’s wish for validation of her own struggles and belief that others with similar illnesses would benefit from the right resources and mutual encouragement on their recovery journey.', quotes=["i would definitely validate what you're feeling even if you haven't found any doctors or any social support that has the same experience ... this program truly could help ... there are people out there who have these product fatigue syndromes whatever they're facing"])]
codes=[Code(slug='fear-of-losing-identity-during-illness', name='Fear of losing identity and sense of self during illness', description='Participants expressed a deep fear of losing their personal identity due to the limitations and isolation imposed by CFS/ME and Long COVID. The illness fundamentally altered how they saw themselves, making them feel disconnected from the life and activities that had previously defined them.', quotes=['...I didn’t recognize myself anymore, I just felt like all I was was sick.', 'I was terrified I’d never get back to the person I was.']), Code(slug='need-for-validation-and-being-believed', name='Longing for validation and need to be believed about symptoms', description='Participants strongly desired that medical professionals, family, and friends acknowledge their illness as real and serious. Not being believed led to feelings of loneliness, frustration, and emotional distress, as their symptoms were often dismissed or minimized.', quotes=['Nobody really believed me when I said I couldn’t get out of bed...', 'It made me feel invisible, like my suffering wasn’t real to anyone except me.', 'I needed someone to just say, ‘I believe you.’']), Code(slug='desire-for-hope-and-possibility-of-recovery', name='Desire for hope and possibility of recovery', description='Maintaining hope for improvement or recovery was central to participants’ emotional wellbeing. When hope felt possible, it gave motivation to try new treatments and persevere, while a lack of hope made symptoms feel unbearable and the future bleak.', quotes=['What kept me going was the hope that I could get my life back.', 'I just needed to see someone who had recovered, to know it was possible.']), Code(slug='need-for-meaning-and-purpose-despite-illness', name='Searching for meaning and purpose despite illness', description='Participants sought ways to rediscover a sense of meaning and purpose in life, even when severely ill. They described a struggle to find activities and connections that brought fulfillment, especially when previous sources of meaning were no longer possible.', quotes=['I had to find something every day to look forward to, even if it was small.', '...when I got sick, I lost my entire sense of purpose.']), Code(slug='demand-for-control-and-autonomy-over-health-decisions', name='Strong need for control and autonomy over health decisions', description='Controlling their own treatment and recovery process was crucial for participants. They described frustration when excluded from medical decisions and desired to experiment with therapies and approaches that felt right for them, rather than passively following others’ plans.', quotes=['It felt important just to decide what I wanted to try...', 'I hated not having control over my own health.'])]
codes=[Code(slug='anger-as-central-pain-driver', name='Feeling anger as the central factor keeping people in pain', description='Participants describe anger as the primary sensation sustaining their chronic symptoms, learned through personal experience and medical practice. This anger is viewed not as a psychological issue, but as a physiological response rooted in threat physiology. This reframing impacts emotional experience, healing, and self-perception.', quotes=['the biggest factor keeping people in pain is anger', "I thought anxiety and anger were psychological constructs... it turns out it's just the sensations generated by your body when you're in fight or flight", 'anger and anxiety are physiological survival responses that we have no control over, zero']), Code(slug='helplessness-and-symptom-fixation', name='Feeling frustration and helplessness from repeated unsuccessful efforts to fix symptoms', description='Participants repeatedly express deep frustration with both the healthcare system and personal attempts to resolve chronic symptoms, detailing unsuccessful medical interventions, persistent suffering, and the futility of fighting symptoms, which ultimately worsened their experience and reinforced pain circuits.', quotes=['I was so frustrated seeing so many people badly damaged by spine surgery', 'thirteen psychotherapy which actually reinforcing the pain circuits not help them', "it wasn't till... things get extremely bad... I sort of gave up fighting", 'the more you try to fight it and solve it the more you reinforce it']), Code(slug='threat-physiology-and-fear', name='Feeling trapped in threat physiology and constant fight or flight', description='The experience of chronic symptoms is deeply intertwined with a sense of being stuck in heightened threat physiology, where anxiety, anger, and physical sensations dominate. Living in this state creates exhaustion, loss of control, and impedes healing, making fear and vigilance a pervasive part of life.', quotes=["if you're stuck in fear loops, if your body feels like it's always on high alert", 'your body breaks down... if you sustain [threat physiology] it really breaks down', "when you're running from a tiger... your thinking centers are markedly compromised and you're just reacting"]), Code(slug='validation-and-relief', name='Feeling validation and relief from hearing physiological explanations for symptoms', description='Participants express profound relief and validation upon learning their symptoms stem from understandable physiological processes, rather than personal weakness or psychological failure. This reframe counters previous invalidation from both internal and external sources and fosters hope and renewed belief in recovery.', quotes=['this is so validating for us going through this to hear this coming from a physician', "it can all sound a little bit that oh you're in all this pain... and you have to look at your emotions and you know this is your path out of this", 'just really incredible and really validating to have so many knowledgeable physicians coming forward and speaking about this']), Code(slug='letting-go-of-pain-identity', name='Feeling improvement by letting go of pain identity and endless symptom discussion', description='Letting go of constant symptom focus and pain-related identity is experienced by participants as a key turning point in recovery. Ceasing to discuss chronic symptoms is described as liberating, leading to unexpected improvements and a shift in attention toward more life-affirming activities.', quotes=['for a year that I was going to stop trying to fix myself... never talking about it again I started to feel better', 'I made a rule because I was tired of it being my whole identity']), Code(slug='skepticism-and-hope-in-recovery', name='Feeling skeptical yet hopeful about non-surgical, skill-based healing approaches', description='Participants convey skepticism toward new healing models, stemming from failed treatments and prevailing medical paradigms, but also acknowledge emerging hope when presented with data and stories of recovery using self-directed, skill-based strategies that challenge conventional interventions.', quotes=['I still hear every day from people... really struggling to believe that I’m going to be able to get rid of them all without surgery or medication', 'people don’t believe it... so when you leave this podcast or tv show don’t believe anything I said the key is connect to what’s in there which is skepticism']), Code(slug='difficulty-letting-go-of-control', name='Feeling challenged by the need to relinquish control and stop self-fixing', description='A recurring struggle is described around the difficulty of letting go of constant efforts to fix oneself and instead focusing on learning new skills and allowing healing. This resistance to ‘not working on the problem’ is seen as the hardest barrier, often interfering with progress and perpetuating symptom cycles.', quotes=['the hardest part of this project by far is people can’t help but try to fix themselves', 'letting go the fixing process is really challenging that’s probably the biggest step is letting go']), Code(slug='self-directed-healing-and-agency', name='Feeling empowered by self-directed healing and learning life skills', description='Participants who shift focus from seeking medical fixes to actively learning skills for calming physiology and changing life patterns describe empowerment and regaining agency. This path is experienced as accessible, practical, and fostering deep healing beyond symptom management, moving toward thriving rather than merely coping.', quotes=['you do not need a pain clinic to do this', 'shouldn’t be work should be curiosity what’s going on you look at it as just learning skills', 'allow your body be a state of physiology your body heals itself'])]
codes=[Code(slug='searching-validation-recovery-path', name='Searching for validation and a recovery path to avoid unnecessary surgery', description='The participant describes intense suffering and the pursuit of answers, specifically seeking a path that brings validation to their pain and a non-surgical recovery route. The urgent desire is for a solution that not only avoids invasive procedures but gives hope and concrete relief after repeated disappointments with standard medical advice.', quotes=['i had back pain ... was going to get surgery while i waited for surgery i found a book ... my back pain was gone within a few months ... went back to all my activities ... a lot of the other health problems i had suffered with for years went away', 'i had heartburn so bad i had surgery for acid reflux which i wish i never had now ... causes problems for me now but ... everything went away']), Code(slug='longing-emotional-understanding-link-pain', name='Longing for emotional understanding and recognition of the link to pain', description='The participant expresses a yearning for recognition of strong emotions as an underlying factor of chronic pain, not just physical causes. There is a wish for emotional experiences to be validated and worked with, highlighting the desire to move beyond purely physical interpretations of pain and receive acknowledgement of emotional realities in treatment.', quotes=["personality characteristics ... really highly motivated ambitious hardworking but also really uncomfortable with strong emotions ... we run around trying to make everyone feel better ... if one person is unhappy we're really upset about that", 'the idea is all emotions are healthy ... we learn early on ... that some emotions are okay healthy and some emotions are really problematic ... we develop strategies ... to protect ourselves and others from these emotions that we learn are not okay']), Code(slug='desire-for-treatment-tailored-emotional-barriers', name='Desire for treatment tailored to individual emotional barriers and defenses', description="The participant voices the need for therapeutic interventions that adjust to the individual's defensive structures and emotional thresholds. There is a clear wish for a process that doesn't overwhelm but incrementally pushes emotional boundaries, recognizing that not everyone is immediately ready to confront painful emotions and that resistance is natural and must be respected.", quotes=["most of the folks that i work with come to me because they know and understand and accept this but ... some folks can work through the process very quickly ... other people it's more complicated and it's harder ... i still am to this day very guarded and defended", "in istdp we're always checking what do you notice in your body as you talk about this person ... often our anger comes in and when we check into the body ... you'll see tension ... that's anxiety ... their bodies are really afraid about this feeling"]), Code(slug='wanting-progress-in-therapy-setbacks-part', name='Wanting progress in therapy and accepting setbacks as part of healing', description='There is a significant desire for tangible progress in therapy but with an acceptance that setbacks and symptom flare-ups are part of the journey of emotional processing. The participant wants to normalize relapses, viewing them as opportunities for growth and transformation, rather than signs of failure, and seeks support to persist through difficult phases in recovery.', quotes=['people get better generally have a setback at some point as things start to get more difficult emotionally ... their symptoms will flare up or new things will happen ... people who really believe in it ... will stick with it ... and get better ... people get better in my study were the ones that believed in it so much at the start that they worked through the setbacks and were able to make a lot of progress after that']), Code(slug='craving-professional-understanding-scientific-legitimacy', name='Craving professional understanding and scientific legitimacy for emotional therapies', description='The participant expresses a strong desire for conventional medical professionals and the broader community to understand and accept emotional therapies for pain. There is a need for scientific legitimacy, institutional adoption, and recognition, so that patients don’t have to hide their experiences and can access validated, effective treatment options openly.', quotes=["as i said hid in the shadows with this ... it's really been incredible to watch the change ... i'm training doctors here in our local hospital on this as part of a community ... even in medical school now ... starting to look to scientifically supported approaches", "there was no pain curriculum medical school and they're starting to have one now ... our approaches have much higher success rates ... research is really supportive"]), Code(slug='yearning-integrated-mind-body-healing', name='Yearning for integrated mind-body healing rather than separation', description='A prevalent desire is for an integrated view of health that brings together physical and mental aspects. The participant resists compartmentalizing physical and mental health, seeking a unified approach that recognizes emotional healing as essential for recovery from chronic conditions, thus reframing therapy as core to physical improvement rather than a peripheral support.', quotes=['most of us think of our ... mental health and our physical health and those are two separate things ... addressing your mental health stuff is a nice to have ... it was just to help me cope with the sickness and keep me going until i found my physical cure ... such a change in mindset and our understanding ... to even get people to the place where they see this as a part of their path to getting better']), Code(slug='needing-supportive-challenge-in-therapy', name='Needing supportive challenge in therapy to expand emotional capacity', description='The participant seeks therapeutic approaches that actively push them slightly beyond their emotional comfort zone in a supportive environment. They yearn for guidance that gradually increases tolerance for emotional pain or difficulty, analogized as training for fitness, with the therapist acting as a coach to ensure neither overwhelming nor stagnation—progressing incrementally in emotional healing.', quotes=["i liken them more to like a walk like walking is really good ... it's easy ... istdp is more like crossfit ... if you really want to change your body ... you got to get in the gym and put the more severe work and that's what i like ... a really supportive crossfit coach ... our therapy should get people to the emotion that they can tolerate deal with without going over because it will have setbacks ... without staying too low because then we won't see progress"])]

themes=[Theme(name='Refusing to accept illness as permanent and relentless hope for improvement', description="This theme centers on participants' ongoing belief that recovery is possible, even after decades of severe illness and setbacks. Despite medical advice to accept limitations, participants described a stubborn optimism and refusal to let illness define their future, expressing persistent hope and denial of permanence. This mindset was an active driver of their behaviors, fueling efforts to seek improvement and new approaches, as captured in repeated statements about never giving up and always seeing possibility.", code_slugs=['relentless-hope-refusal-to-accept-illness-as-final']), Theme(name='Struggling to set boundaries and achieve genuine rest despite ingrained habits', description="Across the interviews, participants expressed ongoing difficulty with overexertion and deeply rooted people-pleasing patterns. Learning to establish boundaries was described as 'the hardest' ongoing challenge, manifesting in behaviors like letting calls go to voicemail and resisting compulsion to 'get things done.' Achieving real, restorative rest required conscious retraining and daily effort to fight habits of distraction and self-neglect, highlighting the exhaustion of constantly needing to prioritize self-care amid internal and external pressures.", code_slugs=['constant-struggle-with-overexertion-and-rest-boundaries', 'developing-boundaries-against-people-pleasing', 'difficulty-attaining-real-rest-and-changing-rest-habits']), Theme(name='Facing emotional impacts of isolation and being misunderstood by others', description="Participants described feeling isolated and emotionally stressed when misunderstood or judged by others, particularly those who minimized or dismissed the reality of ME/CFS. This lack of understanding led to frustration, anger, and a sense of being alone in their struggles. Family support provided solace, yet interactions with outsiders evoked emotional triggers and challenges in managing reactions to ignorance and skepticism about their illness, reinforcing the participant's sense of isolation and emotional strain.", code_slugs=['emotional-impacts-of-isolation-and-misunderstanding-from-others', 'managing-frustration-when-others-dont-understand']), Theme(name='Experiencing identity change through listening to body and making lifestyle shifts', description='This theme captures the transformation experienced by participants as they learned to listen to their body and identify personal triggers. Recovery involved significant lifestyle and identity changes, where participants became attuned to their bodily signals, prioritized their health, and accepted the necessity of ongoing adjustments. The theme reflects a journey of self-discovery, recognition that needs are valid, and movement away from past habits or denial, emphasizing self-awareness as a meaningful outcome.', code_slugs=['identity-change-through-self-discovery-and-listening-to-body']), Theme(name='Difficulty accepting dependence and receiving help during severe illness', description='During periods of acute unwellness, participants felt conflicted about their dependence on others for basic needs. While support from friends and family was indispensable, needing help evoked mixed feelings around vulnerability, loss of autonomy, and emotional discomfort. These experiences were described as necessary yet fraught, with participants expressing struggle to reconcile personal limits and the emotional weight of receiving care in times of incapacity.', code_slugs=['difficulty-accepting-and-receiving-help']), Theme(name='Initial skepticism and emotional resistance to new healing approaches and brain retraining', description='Participants frequently encountered emotional and cognitive barriers when introduced to new therapeutic modalities, particularly psychological or neurological frameworks like brain retraining. Initial reactions included skepticism, resistance, and concern about the legitimacy of such approaches in contrast to biomedical explanations. However, engagement with these therapies sometimes led to improvement and hope as participants reconciled their doubts and found meaning in new paths to recovery.', code_slugs=['challenge-of-trusting-new-healing-methods'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Feeling overwhelmed and seeking reassurance amid unpredictable symptoms', description='Participants describe feeling overwhelmed, confused, and scared by the unpredictable mix and severity of symptoms associated with MECFS. This uncertainty drives them to compare their symptoms with those of others who have recovered, seeking comfort and hope that their own recovery is possible. The desire for reassurance is heightened by the fear that their symptoms may be worse, more numerous, or different than others, creating emotional distress.', code_slugs=['overwhelmed-by-symptom-diversity', 'search-for-reassurance-by-comparing']), Theme(name='Desire for a personalised, holistic recovery approach tailored to individual experience', description='Participants express frustration with attempts to treat symptoms individually, describing these efforts as exhausting and ultimately unsuccessful. Instead, they emphasise the importance of developing a recovery plan that is customised to their unique set of symptoms, lifestyle, and starting point. They reject one-size-fits-all strategies and advocate for supportive approaches that treat the body as a whole, aligning recovery with their personal journey and needs.', code_slugs=['individualised-approach-to-recovery', 'excessive-symptom-focus-is-unhelpful']), Theme(name='Emotional exhaustion and the importance of boundaries in symptom discussions', description="Engagement in symptom discussions, whether sharing personal stories or troubleshooting other people's symptoms, is described as emotionally draining and sometimes traumatising. Participants emphasise the need to set boundaries to protect their emotional wellbeing, choosing to avoid in-depth symptom comparison and to limit public and private exchanges about symptoms after recovery. The process of revisiting symptoms can lead to overwhelm, requiring intentional self-care.", code_slugs=['emotional-cost-of-symptom-discussion']), Theme(name='Skepticism about diagnostic labels and focus on personal severity and impact', description='Participants are ambivalent about the value of labels such as MECFS, post-viral fatigue, or long COVID. They feel that diagnostic labels do not affect the real experience or recovery and argue for focusing on the personal impact and severity of symptoms rather than rigid definitions. Labels may have practical uses, but do not provide emotional relief or change the lived reality of illness or recovery.', code_slugs=['labels-provide-little-relief-or-clarity'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Feeling like life is a miracle after years of suffering', description='Participants describe life after recovery as living a miracle, full of childlike wonder and gratitude. This theme captures the sense of having a second chance at life, never wanting to become "a normal person who takes it for granted." The renewed appreciation for everyday experiences, described as enlivening and as "winning the race every day," highlights how surviving chronic illness profoundly shapes ongoing joy and perspective.', code_slugs=['second-chance-at-life-renewed-gratitude', 'accepting-imperfection-health']), Theme(name='Experiencing deep emotional separation from those without chronic illness', description='This theme reflects the strong feelings of alienation and detachment participants have from friends and peers who haven’t experienced chronic illness. Complaints about ordinary stressors like work or exercise become emotional triggers, as participants struggle with people who take their health for granted. The lack of shared experience leads to difficulty relating and maintaining friendships, emphasizing the lingering emotional gap chronic illness constructs.', code_slugs=['detachment-friends-chronic-illness']), Theme(name='Transforming self-worth from achievement to unconditional acceptance and humility', description='Participants reveal a dramatic shift in self-identity after illness. Formerly anchored in professional achievement and productivity, identity becomes rooted in a deeper sense of worth and humility. The experience of accepting help, being valued regardless of accomplishments, and finding support from others emerges as crucial. Illness humbles participants and offers greater appreciation of human connection and intrinsic value.', code_slugs=['identity-self-worth-achievement-loss']), Theme(name='Recognizing and healing psychological and spiritual wounds as part of recovery', description='Recovery from chronic illness encompasses more than physical healing. This theme captures the need for mind-body work, trauma healing, spiritual growth, and letting go of fear and control. Participants describe spiritual practices and prayer as transformative, giving meaning and depth to their journey. The process is described as surrendering, regaining faith, and integrating all aspects of self into lasting recovery.', code_slugs=['healing-trauma-mind-body', 'positive-growth-spirituality-illness', 'giving-up-control-pregnancy-anxiety']), Theme(name='Enduring desperation driving radical lifestyle transformation for health', description='Desperation is a pivotal emotional driver for change. Facing severe symptoms, participants become willing to endure drastic and difficult lifestyle modifications, including elimination diets, removal of environmental toxins, and adapting movement routines. The theme highlights the struggle, reliance on support, and how feeling “so desperate” finally makes the previously unthinkable possible for the chance to reclaim life.', code_slugs=['lifestyle-modification-desperation']), Theme(name='Finding freedom and relief after overcoming food addiction and cravings', description='This theme focuses on participants’ intense battle with food addiction—especially sugar—and the profound liberation felt once food is no longer a source of struggle. Recovery brings an end to lifelong cravings, replacing desperation with a healthy relationship to food. Describing their path as “freedom,” participants value this transformation as one of their most meaningful outcomes, removing a persistent barrier to wellbeing.', code_slugs=['freedom-food-addiction-overcome']), Theme(name='Embracing hope and inspiration from the stories of others who have recovered', description='Seeing and hearing about others’ recovery is vital for participants’ motivation and belief in the possibility of wellness. This theme centers around the impact of recovery stories on resilience, the need to reject limiting medical prognoses, and the significance of “undeniable evidence” that people do get better. Participants cherish these stories as lifelines and fuel during the hardest moments.', code_slugs=['hope-recovery-others-inspiration', 'connection-community-survivors']), Theme(name='Accepting imperfection and normal fluctuations after chronic illness', description='Participants grapple with anxiety over possible relapse, learning to distinguish normal discomforts from returning symptoms. This theme captures the process of recognizing imperfection in recovery—"getting better doesn\'t mean perfection"—and cultivating self-compassion. Comparing themselves to “normal healthy people” who have headaches or bad days, participants actively draw boundaries and remind themselves of what is common and expected.', code_slugs=['accepting-imperfection-health', 'giving-up-control-pregnancy-anxiety']), Theme(name='Rejecting quick fixes and symptom chasing in favor of holistic approaches', description='Participants find that chasing individual symptoms with pills or supplements proves ineffective for long-term recovery. Instead, they discover the necessity of root-cause, holistic strategies tailored to personal needs. This theme articulates the futility of seeking universal solutions, with supplements only working based on specific blood work and genetic profiles, and highlights the wisdom gained from focusing on core healing.', code_slugs=['chasing-symptoms-not-working']), Theme(name='Encountering and responding to skepticism about illness and recovery', description='Recovery brings challenges beyond healing, including doubts from others about the authenticity of illness and recovery. This theme encompasses participants’ experiences of skepticism, feeling attacked, and their choice to respond with confidence rather than defensiveness. The struggle to validate their stories and the importance of knowing their own truth become ongoing elements of the post-recovery journey.', code_slugs=['doubt-skepticism-recovery'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Experiencing profound loss, isolation, and grief after sudden chronic illness diagnosis', description='Participants described overwhelming loss of independence and social connection after illness onset at a young age. Medical misunderstanding fueled despair as doctors dismissed their symptoms as mere depression. This period brought shock, emotional struggle, and deep grief, with feelings of being scared, alone, and disconnected from peers and normal life. The search for validation and a true diagnosis intensified emotional suffering and the sense of not being understood.', code_slugs=['initial-overwhelm-loss-isolation-young-adult', 'despair-grief-not-understood-medical-disbelief']), Theme(name='Pursuing every possible avenue for healing amid desperation and fluctuating hope', description='Desperation to recover drove participants to exhaustively pursue therapies, from acupuncture to reiki, colonic irrigation, and even overseas healers. Temporary relief from meditation, yoga, breathwork, and relaxation sparked moments of hope, though these were fleeting. This theme highlights the continual experimentation, sense of urgency, and willingness to try anything to escape suffering and find sustainable improvement, even when many attempts led to disappointment.', code_slugs=['desperate-search-healing-experiments-trials', 'hope-small-wins-alternative-practices-coping']), Theme(name='Discovering emotional suppression, unresolved trauma, and the mind-body connection', description='A turning point in recovery was the recognition that suppressed anger, avoidance of conflict, and unresolved trauma were linked to physical symptoms. Emotional triggers led to fatigue and shutdowns, and reverse therapy helped participants tune into their feelings. This theme highlights the realization that healing required processing emotions and understanding how trauma manifested physically, bridging psychological work with improvements in health and sense of self.', code_slugs=['recognizing-suppressed-emotions-key-recovery', 'exploring-mind-body-connection-physical-symptoms']), Theme(name='Learning authentic self-expression, emotional balance, and prioritizing self care', description='Recovery depended on expressing needs and feelings authentically, moving from suppression to balanced communication. Training in nonviolent communication and prioritizing self-care practices—time in nature, supportive friendships, and balanced work—were named as foundational. This theme highlights the process of becoming more authentic, learning it’s okay to have needs, and establishing habits that support sustainable wellbeing in work and relationships.', code_slugs=['learning-authentic-self-expression-self-care']), Theme(name='Experiencing spiritual awakening and dissociation during intense meditation practice', description='Participants recounted periods of spiritual awakening and mystical experiences tied to meditation, sometimes resulting in dissociation and difficulty integrating into everyday reality. While these moments provided beauty and a sense of universal connection, they also challenged practical functioning and healing. This theme explores both the allure and the drawbacks of deep spiritual experiences in the context of chronic illness recovery.', code_slugs=['spiritual-awakening-dissociation-meditation']), Theme(name='Experiencing transformative personal growth, ongoing joy, and lifelong learning after recovery', description='Following recovery, participants gained deep inner peace, joy, and curiosity. The journey fostered interest in personal growth, wellbeing practices, and community, creating a sense of fulfillment and a commitment to lifelong learning. Experiences such as running marathons, raising a child, and exploring new therapeutic practices highlight how adversity fueled growth and sustained curiosity for new possibilities.', code_slugs=['long-term-personal-growth-ongoing-joy-curiosity']), Theme(name='Maintaining wellbeing by managing residual trauma symptoms with regulation practices', description='After recovery, participants still experienced periodic trauma symptoms, such as feeling shut down or dissociated. They learned to use targeted self-care, therapeutic support, and connection with nature for regulation. Recovery was described as an ongoing journey, requiring continued attention to emotional and physical balance, especially in dealing with past trauma’s lingering effects.', code_slugs=['managing-residual-trauma-practices-post-recovery']), Theme(name='Building a meaningful career in therapeutic coaching inspired by lived experience of illness', description='Personal experience with chronic illness shaped participants’ career trajectories toward therapeutic coaching and trauma work. Training in modalities like bodywork, the Gupta Program, and internal family systems was motivated by recovery experiences. This theme highlights how professional choices were deeply informed by wanting to support others using learned evidence-based practices and personal insights.', code_slugs=['career-shift-meaningful-work-trauma-coaching']), Theme(name='Gaining understanding of ancestral trauma and the impact of family illness patterns', description='Participants developed insight into the influence of ancestral trauma and family-system illness patterns on their own health. Family constellations and systemic therapy expanded the view beyond personal trauma to transgenerational effects, questioning how family history creates vulnerability. This theme reflects an evolving awareness of the roots and recurrence of chronic illness within wider family systems.', code_slugs=['awareness-ancestral-trauma-family-patterns'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Experiencing devastation, grief, and powerlessness after diagnosis and medical interventions', description='This theme captures the deep emotional devastation, fear, grief, and sense of powerlessness following the onset of ME/CFS, receiving a life-changing diagnosis, and encountering medical care that imposed restrictive treatments. Participants felt powerless, as decisions were made for them rather than with them. Their meaningful losses included careers, relationships, and identity, with a sense of deprivation and lack of agency intensifying feelings of despair and bereavement.', code_slugs=['devastation-diagnosis-life-sentence', 'powerlessness-medical-system-agency', 'grief-loss-career-relationships']), Theme(name='Discovering inner hope, spiritual strength, and reclaiming personal agency for healing', description='Participants describe an enduring inner source of hope and spiritual connection that helped them survive isolation and depression. Over time, discovering the role of personal agency, intuition, and making choices that feel right became crucial to their recovery. Healing was only possible when the participant actively participated and trusted their own desires, relying on spirituality, yoga, and meditation to foster resilience and self-belief.', code_slugs=['hope-spirituality-source-strength', 'personal-agency-choice-healing']), Theme(name='Learning self-compassion, releasing suppressed emotions, and softening self-criticism', description='This theme describes how recovery involved shifting from chronic self-judgment and pressure to nurturing self-compassion, using practices like expressive journaling to release suppressed anger and grief. Participants noted that perfectionism and people-pleasing contributed to bottled-up emotions, compounding internal stress. Engaging with self-compassion and emotional release softened the blow of losses and promoted both emotional and physical healing.', code_slugs=['self-compassion-instead-criticism', 'expression-of-emotions-release']), Theme(name='Experiencing intense joy, gratitude, and personal growth after recovery', description='After years of debilitating symptoms, recovery led to powerful feelings of joy, gratitude, and appreciation for everyday life, which previously felt inaccessible. Participants expressed a sense of rebirth and transformation, describing illness as a catalyst for personal growth, authenticity, and acceptance. The journey fostered resilience, balance, and a drive to be true to oneself, resulting in lasting stability and satisfaction.', code_slugs=['joyful-appreciation-after-recovery', 'personal-growth-gift-trauma']), Theme(name='Feeling called to provide knowledge, compassion, and supportive community for others', description='Recovery inspired a strong desire to help others facing similar struggles by sharing stories, resources, and compassionate support. Participants felt a sense of purpose and fulfillment in coaching, teaching, and connecting with people who seek hope and understanding. Building community and providing knowledge became meaningful outcomes, as did serving as a lifeline and helping others learn, heal, and grow.', code_slugs=['desire-to-help-community'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Experiencing frustration and isolation in finding answers for persistent fatigue', description='This theme captures participants’ feelings of being dismissed by doctors despite ongoing symptoms and the resulting frustration and sense of abandonment. The need for validation, social support, and connection with others facing similar health challenges emerges when formal healthcare fails to provide answers. Participants want to be acknowledged and connected to peers who share their journey.', code_slugs=['doctor-dismissal-frustration', 'desire-validation-peer-support']), Theme(name='Transforming mindset through empowering language, positivity, and growth-oriented social circles', description='Participants describe a shift to using empowering statements and surrounding themselves with people who challenge themselves and seek improvement. This transformation is marked by adopting affirmations that focus on journey and progress rather than feeling stuck, which supports emotional recovery. The desire to cultivate positivity and seek company with a growth mindset reflects their changed outlook and affiliations.', code_slugs=['growth-mindset-affiliations', 'empowerment-language-shift']), Theme(name='Gaining confidence by using novel recovery tools and personalized support', description='Participants experience meaningful progress and excitement when adopting new brain retraining and recovery tools. Skepticism gives way to belief through rapid improvement and personalized support from program leaders who provide encouragement and validation. Having access to individualized communication and resources fosters hope, perseverance, and a sense of being believed in during recovery.', code_slugs=['skepticism-brain-retraining-techniques', 'positive-affect-techniques-rapid-progress', 'importance-personal-support-program']), Theme(name='Learning to accept ongoing symptoms and rely on coping strategies for lasting wellbeing', description='Participants recognize that symptoms like tiredness and anxiety may persist, but having recovery tools allows them to manage setbacks. They describe a practical approach, accepting incomplete recovery while focusing on coping strategies and emotional regulation. This theme reflects a realistic perspective, marking the shift from fear and helplessness to confidence in addressing health challenges as they arise.', code_slugs=['mental-questioning-link-symptoms', 'incomplete-recovery-tools-coping']), Theme(name='Rediscovering motivation for physical activity and challenging the body post-recovery', description='After regaining health, participants feel driven to re-engage in physically demanding activities, such as running races or training for marathons. Their transformed mindset and new techniques boost stamina and motivation, helping them challenge their bodies and set ambitious goals, which had previously felt impossible due to lost energy and motivation.', code_slugs=['gradual-loss-energy-motivation', 'restored-physical-challenge-motivation'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Struggling to hold onto identity and sense of self during illness', description='This theme captures the profound fear and emotional pain experienced by participants as their illness eroded their sense of personal identity. The isolation and dramatic loss of familiar roles left them feeling unrecognizable and disconnected from who they were before. Their suffering was marked by a sense of being ‘just sick’ and a deep worry about never regaining their former selves.', code_slugs=['fear-of-losing-identity-during-illness']), Theme(name='Desperate need for validation and acknowledgment of symptoms', description='Participants felt intense frustration and sadness when medical professionals, family, or friends dismissed or doubted their illness. Not being believed made them feel invisible and emotionally isolated, amplifying their distress. Their experiences underscore a longing for someone to say ‘I believe you’ and recognize that their suffering is real and significant.', code_slugs=['need-for-validation-and-being-believed']), Theme(name='Clinging to hope and possibility of recovery for emotional survival', description='Maintaining hope was a lifeline for participants facing debilitating symptoms. The awareness that recovery was possible motivated them to pursue treatments and persevere through hardship, while hopelessness made everything feel unbearable. Seeing evidence of others recovering provided confirmation and drove their desire to reclaim their lives.', code_slugs=['desire-for-hope-and-possibility-of-recovery']), Theme(name='Rediscovering meaning and purpose through small daily acts despite illness', description='Participants actively pursued ways to find meaning and fulfillment despite profound loss. Illness disrupted their previous sources of purpose, forcing them to seek out activities and connections, no matter how small, that brought hope and joy. The daily struggle to find something to look forward to was vital for emotional resilience and well-being.', code_slugs=['need-for-meaning-and-purpose-despite-illness']), Theme(name='Protecting autonomy and asserting control over personal health decisions', description='Loss of control over medical decisions and treatment was a significant source of distress for participants. They desired to actively decide their own course of recovery, rather than passively following directives. This need for autonomy included experimenting with therapies and choosing options that felt right, highlighting a strong demand for self-determination during illness.', code_slugs=['demand-for-control-and-autonomy-over-health-decisions'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Experiencing frustration and helplessness from failed symptom-fixing and invalidating treatments', description='Participants vividly describe feeling deep frustration and helplessness caused by unsuccessful medical interventions and repeated attempts to fix chronic symptoms. They report that these futile efforts not only reinforce pain but also erode hope, especially when faced with invalidating explanations and poor surgical outcomes. Letting go of relentless focus on symptoms and pain-related identity is described as profoundly liberating, fostering new possibilities for improvement.', code_slugs=['helplessness-and-symptom-fixation', 'letting-go-of-pain-identity']), Theme(name='Feeling relief, validation, and renewed hope from physiological explanations for suffering', description='Participants share the immense comfort and validation received from learning that their chronic symptoms are rooted in understandable, physiological processes. This reframing, offered by knowledgeable physicians, counters previous feelings of shame and disbelief, and opens a path to hope in skill-based, non-surgical healing. The scientific recognition of physiological responses such as threat physiology and anger as survival mechanisms deeply resonates and inspires optimism for recovery.', code_slugs=['validation-and-relief', 'anger-as-central-pain-driver', 'skepticism-and-hope-in-recovery']), Theme(name='Struggling with constant vigilance and exhaustion caused by threat physiology and anxiety loops', description='Participants consistently report feeling trapped in a state of threat physiology and fight or flight, marked by relentless fear, anxiety, vigilance, and loss of control. This chronic state is described as exhausting, physically and emotionally draining, and disrupts thinking and daily life. The difficulty in relinquishing control and stopping attempts to self-fix compounds these struggles, making recovery even more challenging.', code_slugs=['threat-physiology-and-fear', 'difficulty-letting-go-of-control']), Theme(name='Finding empowerment and agency in self-directed, skill-based healing processes', description='Shifting away from dependence on medical fixes and toward practical, self-directed learning is described as profoundly empowering by participants. Gaining skills to calm physiology and change life patterns offers a sense of agency and renewal, supporting deep healing and thriving beyond mere symptom management. The ability to cultivate curiosity, nurture joy, and allow the body to heal itself stands central to meaningful improvement.', code_slugs=['self-directed-healing-and-agency', 'letting-go-of-pain-identity'])]
themes=[Theme(name='Yearning for scientific legitimacy and integrated mind-body recovery approaches', description='Participants express a pervasive desire for emotional therapies to be understood, validated, and adopted by mainstream medical professionals. They recount hiding in the shadows due to lack of scientific legitimacy, craving open acknowledgment that emotional healing is central to recovery. They seek a shift from compartmentalizing physical and mental health to a unified approach where emotion-focused therapy is accepted as essential for conditions like back pain, fibromyalgia, and long covid.', code_slugs=['craving-professional-understanding-scientific-legitimacy', 'yearning-integrated-mind-body-healing']), Theme(name='Seeking tailored, supportive therapeutic challenge for emotional healing', description="Participants want therapy that incrementally expands their emotional capacity, likening the process to crossfit training rather than a walk. They need a supportive coach in therapy who sets the right challenge according to their individual threshold, respecting emotional defenses, setbacks, and readiness. The desire is for a treatment journey that feels safe, adaptable and pushes progress without overwhelming, accommodating each person's guarded structures and barriers.", code_slugs=['desire-for-treatment-tailored-emotional-barriers', 'needing-supportive-challenge-in-therapy']), Theme(name='Longing for validation and concrete relief through emotion-focused recovery', description='Participants show a strong longing to have their pain and health struggles validated, searching for recovery paths—like avoiding unnecessary surgery—where emotional understanding is recognized as central. They need treatment that acknowledges powerful emotions behind chronic pain, normalizes setbacks as part of healing, and supports persistence and hope for tangible progress, rooting recovery in emotional processing and personal belief in the approach.', code_slugs=['searching-validation-recovery-path', 'longing-emotional-understanding-link-pain', 'wanting-progress-in-therapy-setbacks-part'])]

You are a: {{persona}}

{{research_question}}

## Preliminary codes

<text>
{{all_codes}}
</text>

First, make a short list of notes on the codes we want to keep. Avoid duplicates. Just list the names of the codes we will keep.


[[codenotes]]

Now, form this list of new/aligned codes into the required format.

A code consists of

- A concise name (8-15 words)
- A codename/slug (max 20 letters a-Z)
- A meaningful description (around 50 words)
- Representative quotes from the text (abbreviated with ellipses if needed)
