You are a: Experienced qual researcher

None

We are now going to rationalise the set of codes identified across multiple documents. We will consolidate into a single CodeList.

## Preliminary codes

<text>
codes=[Code(slug='relentless-hope-refusal-to-accept-illness-as-final', name='Relentless hope and refusal to accept illness as a permanent fate', description='This code captures the participant’s enduring belief that recovery was possible, despite extensive periods of severe illness and advice to accept limitations. The participant’s positivity, obstinacy, and near denial of the permanence of ME/CFS framed her experience and motivated continued efforts towards improvement and healing.', quotes=['i never ever felt in fact i was almost like in denial', "you're not going to tell me how i'm going to be for the rest of my life", "i've never ever thought i'm not going to get better you know i've always thought i know i can i can get on top of it maybe not be healed from it", "even when i was tired i wouldn't let myself not go", 'part is just my personality is like that i never ever felt in fact i was almost like in denial']), Code(slug='constant-struggle-with-overexertion-and-rest-boundaries', name='Constant struggle with overexertion and learning boundaries for rest', description='This code reflects the participant’s recurring challenge with pushing herself beyond her limits, compelled by past habits and personality, and the subsequent learning process to respect her boundaries. Overexertion led to severe crashes, prompting her to gradually recognize the importance of self-imposed limits and rest.', quotes=['i kept pushing myself pushing myself', "even when i was tired i wouldn't let myself not go", "i'm not good at relaxing i'm really really not good at relaxing", 'the hardest for me was learning boundaries', "i now can stop myself before i actually get to the stage where i'm really pushing pushing boundaries"]), Code(slug='difficulty-accepting-and-receiving-help', name='Difficulty accepting and needing help during severe illness periods', description='This code centers on the participant’s experience of dependency during periods of extreme unwellness. Receiving practical support from friends and family was necessary but emotionally fraught, making her feel conflicted about her limitations and need for care.', quotes=['i had quite a support group lovely support group who fetched and carried and did everything for me', 'i had a lady that used to do the cooking', 'when i had to start doing my own cooking washing and everything else i was back to square one']), Code(slug='emotional-impacts-of-isolation-and-misunderstanding-from-others', name='Emotional impacts of isolation and being misunderstood by others', description='This code highlights the participant’s feelings of being misunderstood or judged, especially by those who did not understand ME/CFS. Feeling isolated in her experience, she expressed frustration and emotional stress when confronted with others’ minimization or ignorance about her condition.', quotes=["mustn't isolate yourself no no no you're doing this all wrong because you're becoming a recluse", "they never understood it then they certainly don't understand it now", 'when somebody minimizes it you can think no', 'i can flare up when people say silly things sometimes']), Code(slug='identity-change-through-self-discovery-and-listening-to-body', name='Identity change through self-discovery and listening to body signals', description='This code reflects the participant’s transformation as she began listening to her body, recognizing triggers and needs. This process marked a lifestyle and identity shift, as she learned to prioritize her health, respect her limits, and view her needs as valid.', quotes=["i've learnt to listen to myself listen to my body i think that's so yes there's been a lifestyle change in a way", "it's been a journey of getting to know myself work out what my triggers are", 'learning what i need to do to keep myself healthy instead of going back if that makes sense to you']), Code(slug='challenge-of-trusting-new-healing-methods', name='Challenge of trusting and engaging with new healing approaches', description='This code describes the participant’s skepticism and emotional resistance towards new therapeutic frameworks, particularly brain retraining. She struggled with accepting that her recovery could involve psychological or neurological processes, yet ultimately found hope and improvement through these methods.', quotes=["my first reaction was oh no raylan no when do you start telling me it's all on my brain", "i was not impressed i thought no i'm going to find somebody else to watch", 'then working with jason it was quite soon as soon as i you know he he goes through like relaxation']), Code(slug='developing-boundaries-against-people-pleasing', name='Developing boundaries against ingrained people-pleasing tendencies', description='The participant identified lifelong patterns of people pleasing as barriers to rest, recovery, and well-being. She describes deliberate, ongoing efforts to set boundaries in social interactions, ignore non-essential demands, and put her own needs first, which required significant behavioral change.', quotes=['a lot of people with chronic fatigue are people pleasers', "there's things i've had to put in place where you know like if my phone rings i let it go to voicemail if it's not you know if it's one of my children", 'now i do let my phone go to voicemail and i can just ignore it']), Code(slug='difficulty-attaining-real-rest-and-changing-rest-habits', name='Difficulty attaining real rest and actively retraining rest habits', description='This code captures the participant’s realization that her rest was not truly restorative, and required conscious effort to change. She consistently struggled to rest without distraction, needing to actively cultivate new habits for genuine rejuvenation by resisting impulses to check devices or respond to others.', quotes=["i'm not good at resting i really am not as you say i'll sit there for a bit and then i think let me just see what's on my phone", 'being aware of the things that encroach in your life like the phones in the evenings i just leave mine in the lounge when i go to bed', "i actually smile and i say to myself in my head i'm like real rest"]), Code(slug='managing-frustration-when-others-dont-understand', name='Managing frustration and emotional reactions when others don’t understand', description='This code reflects the participant’s experiences of irritation, anger, and emotional triggers when others expressed ignorance, skepticism, or minimization about ME/CFS. She describes trying to remain disengaged from these provocations but admits it still challenges her emotional equilibrium.', quotes=['i can flare up when people say silly things sometimes', "sometimes i will just flare up when somebody says something that clearly shows you don't understand", "why are you even pretending to try and understand when you're not even you're not"])]
codes=[Code(slug='overwhelmed-by-symptom-diversity', name='Feeling overwhelmed and scared by the diversity of symptoms experienced', description='Participants express confusion, overwhelm, and fear when faced with the sudden or gradual onset of a wide array of symptoms associated with MECFS, such as fatigue, pain, memory issues, and sensitivities. The unpredictable combination and intensity of symptoms create distress and challenges in knowing how to respond or where to begin addressing their health concerns.', quotes=['there can be such a crazy mix of symptoms coming at you...this onslaught of new symptoms can be overwhelming and confusing and scary', 'whether these symptoms come on suddenly or slowly creep up over time...can be overwhelming and confusing and scary']), Code(slug='search-for-reassurance-by-comparing', name='Seeking reassurance and hope by comparing symptoms with others who have recovered', description='Participants desire to compare their own symptoms against those of others who have recovered from MECFS as a way to gauge their prospects for recovery. They hope to find someone with similar symptoms as affirmation that recovery is possible for them, which provides comfort and reassurance amid uncertainty.', quotes=["i think the first reason that this is happening...people want to see if we're the same if my symptoms match your symptoms and i recovered then that means that there's good hope that you can recover", "...you want reassurance that it's still possible for you too to heal and i just want to say yes it is possible for you to heal no matter how random crazy or numerous your symptoms"]), Code(slug='individualised-approach-to-recovery', name='Desire for a recovery approach personalised to own symptoms and circumstances', description='Participants express the need for a recovery plan tailored to their unique experience, symptoms, starting point, and lifestyle. They acknowledge that different strategies, treatments, and pacing must be customised for their specific situation, rejecting one-size-fits-all solutions and symptom comparisons for developing recovery paths.', quotes=['build your recovery plan for you...make this personal to you', '...just like pacing has to be tailored individually for a particular person because their life is so different...needs to be tailored as well', "stay true to what's going to work for you...your whole makeup will be different"]), Code(slug='excessive-symptom-focus-is-unhelpful', name='Frustration with the emphasis on treating symptoms individually', description='Participants report that focusing intensely on managing and fixing each symptom separately did not lead to actual recovery. They describe the efforts as exhausting, costly, and ultimately unhelpful, instead advocating for a more holistic body-wide approach. They feel frustrated by the expectation to troubleshoot and compare symptoms for solutions.', quotes=['this never really got me anywhere because this illness can express itself in so many different ways and for me recovery ended up being not about focusing on symptoms and treating specific symptoms but on supporting my body as a whole', "i needed a more comprehensive strategy to actually heal that didn't involve just trying to stop all my symptoms one by one", "...comparing your symptoms to somebody else's and are yours worse or better than theirs...i really encourage people not to get too caught up in"]), Code(slug='emotional-cost-of-symptom-discussion', name='Emotional exhaustion and boundaries in discussing symptoms with others', description="Participants articulate the emotional cost and trauma of repeatedly discussing their own or others' symptoms, both publicly and privately. Reflecting on past suffering or troubleshooting symptoms can be overwhelming, requiring boundaries to protect themselves, such as avoiding one-on-one symptom discussions and preserving emotional wellbeing after recovery.", quotes=['...i actually know quite a few people who recovered who share their story and then got overwhelmed by all the messages and then they left social media because it was just too much', "i myself am an empathetic person but i'm also a person who now has boundaries and one of my boundaries is not talking about my old symptoms with other people and also not talking about their symptoms with them either", "even writing my own story on my blog honestly took me forever because it's pretty traumatizing going back there"]), Code(slug='labels-provide-little-relief-or-clarity', name='Skepticism about diagnostic labels and distinctions in MECFS experience', description='Participants express ambivalence or skepticism about the value of labels such as MECFS, post-viral fatigue, or long COVID. They suggest that such labels do not affect the lived experience or recovery trajectory, and argue that it is more important to focus on severity and impact than rigid diagnosis. Labels sometimes help with practical matters, but do not alter the emotional reality.', quotes=["i'm really not a fan of labels...have i still got post viral fatigue or is this mecfs...it doesn't change anything what it's called doesn't suddenly change how you're feeling or how long you've had it or how long it's going to take you to recover", "labels don't make a difference and comparing your symptoms to somebody else's and are yours worse or better than theirs...don't get too caught up in"])]
codes=[Code(slug='second-chance-at-life-renewed-gratitude', name='Feeling like I have a second chance at life and renewed gratitude', description='After recovery, the participant describes life as feeling like a miracle: each day is appreciated with childlike wonder and gratitude, contrasting with former hopelessness. She hopes to never take this for granted, recognizing the privilege of experiencing "life as a dream" after years of suffering. This renewed perspective is profound and persistent.', quotes=['life opened up...i got a second chance at life', "i couldn't even picture my future before...now...who knows what will happen", "you are a walking miracle...your life is a dream whatever it is that's stressing you out does not matter", 'may i never forget and become...a normal person who takes it for granted', "that joy is so enlivening...every day you're winning the race", 'almost be childlike again and just really appreciate things so much']), Code(slug='detachment-friends-chronic-illness', name='Feeling detached from friends who have not experienced chronic illness', description='The participant expresses difficulty relating to friends who complain about everyday problems, experiencing detachment because they haven’t suffered chronic illness. She struggles to hear complaints about things she longed for—like working out or working—when she was ill, highlighting a gap in shared understanding and a lingering emotional trigger.', quotes=['i just feel such a detachment sometimes', 'i really struggle with people who...seem physically able to go to the gym but just choose not to', "it's hard for me to be their friend now because i'm like you have it all", 'people are entitled to complain about their lives...their problems are real']), Code(slug='living-in-denial-illness-progression', name='Living in denial about the seriousness of illness despite worsening symptoms', description='Early in her illness, the participant describes continuing to work despite collapsing from exhaustion and risking patient safety, reflecting a period of denial about the severity of her condition. She describes eventual realization that illness required her full attention, but this transition involved anxiety and fear.', quotes=['the first year was...me living in denial', 'i would continue to try to work and people would pull me aside like this is dangerous', "i didn't feel safe riding the subway...thought i'd fall asleep or pass out", 'i just kept trying and then...took me a while to realize this was serious']), Code(slug='lifestyle-modification-desperation', name='Desperation motivating dramatic lifestyle modifications for recovery', description='In recovery, desperation pushed the participant to drastic changes—such as restrictive elimination diets, environmental toxin removal, and movement routines—despite initial resistance and difficulty. She highlights the hardship of these changes, needing help with meals, and a willingness to endure discomfort for the possibility of regaining health.', quotes=["level of desperation because it is hard but you get to a point where you're so desperate...you'll do just about anything to get your health back", "it was stressful and it's very hard to do...i was honestly too sick to cook for myself", 'tried really hard...would cheat and fall off and then come back to it before i really got serious', 'i had to dramatically change my diet', 'i had to remove all toxic ingredients']), Code(slug='freedom-food-addiction-overcome', name='Experiencing freedom after overcoming food cravings and addiction', description='The participant details a former intense addiction to sugar and certain foods, involving uncontrollable cravings—even eating sugar from the canister nightly. Recovery brought a healthy relationship with food, where cravings diminished, and eating was no longer a battle. This shift is described as liberating and transformative, removing a lifelong struggle.', quotes=['sugar was a massive one for me...physical addiction...intense', 'i would get up in the middle of the night every single night and eat sugar', 'take a spoon and eat it right out of the canister', 'once my body started healing the cravings went away', "it just feels like freedom...healthy relationship with food where it's not a battle"]), Code(slug='healing-trauma-mind-body', name='Recognizing the need to heal trauma and incorporate mind-body practices', description='The participant identifies trauma healing, spiritual growth, and mind-body work as essential to recovery. She emphasizes that recovery wasn’t only physical but required addressing psychological and spiritual dimensions. There was a process of letting go of control and seeking meaning, which proved vital alongside medical interventions.', quotes=['i did have to go back and heal trauma', 'i had to do some spiritual healing', 'some mind body work', "i had to give my life over...didn't want to live in fear"]), Code(slug='giving-up-control-pregnancy-anxiety', name='Learning to give up control and coping with anxiety during pregnancy', description="Pregnancy after chronic illness challenged the participant to relinquish control and face new fears. She describes anxiety about symptoms reoccurring and differentiating normal pregnancy symptoms from illness. Accepting uncertainty and trusting her body's resilience is both triggering and healing, highlighting ongoing emotional complexity.", quotes=['set me on a course of learning how to give up control in a whole nother way', "it's triggering sometimes to be like is this normal fatigue or is this going back", "reminding myself no it's normal to have headaches when you're pregnant", 'i think in a way this experience is healing in itself']), Code(slug='identity-self-worth-achievement-loss', name='Transforming sense of identity and self-worth after losing achievements', description='She describes a shift in her self-concept, formerly rooted in her career and achievements as an occupational therapist. Illness forced her to reevaluate her value, realizing worth beyond accomplishment, and learning to accept help and love from others. This mind shift brought humility, depth, and greater appreciation of life.', quotes=['how i saw my identity how i valued myself was on my achievements and that was taken away', 'i had to realize that my value was deeper than that', 'people love me people want to help me i could learn to accept that', 'humbled me changed me']), Code(slug='positive-growth-spirituality-illness', name='Experiencing positive personal growth and deeper spirituality from illness', description='Illness propelled personal growth, humility, and spiritual connection for the participant. She describes formerly lacking spirituality, but desperation led to faith and prayer—"the simplest thing which is free." This growth is enduring, changing her perspective on life and gratitude, with illness serving as a catalyst for self-improvement and deeper meaning.', quotes=["i wouldn't say i had a spirituality before...relationship with god...took me getting so sick and so desperate", 'willing to pray like the simplest thing which is free', "never be the person i was before and i'm thankful for that", 'appreciate life more']), Code(slug='hope-recovery-others-inspiration', name="Valuing hope and seeing stories of other people's recovery as inspiration", description='The participant finds motivation and hope from seeing others recover from illness, recalling how critical recovery stories were for her own belief and perseverance. themes.name: Clinging to inner hope and refusing to accept illness as a permanent fate shapes every step of recovery
themes.description: Participants hold an unwavering belief in the possibility of improvement, even in the face of prolonged illness and repeated setbacks. This stubborn optimism and refusal to be defined by diagnoses fuel their engagement with therapies and new approaches. The drive to witness others’ success stories and persistent hope creates ongoing resilience, making hope itself a practical and emotional lifeline that influences all efforts toward healing.

themes.name: Profound emotional isolation, loss, and longing for validation after misunderstood illness
themes.description: Participants wrestle with feelings of grief and isolation as the impact of chronic illness is frequently minimized or misunderstood by friends, family, and medical professionals. The struggle to be believed and emotionally understood creates a powerful need for validation. Emotional triggers lead to detachment from previously close relationships, amplifying distress and the sense of being ‘just sick’ and invisible.

themes.name: Radical transformation of identity and self-worth after losing achievements and confronting change
themes.description: Illness forces a dramatic shift away from achievement-based self-worth toward unconditional acceptance, humility, and self-discovery. Participants describe learning to listen to bodily signals, transforming how they relate to themselves, and moving through fear that their old selves are lost. This transformation is marked by deeper connection to intrinsic value, authenticity, and recognition of personal limits and needs.

themes.name: Learning boundaries, self-care, and letting go of ingrained habits for lasting wellbeing
themes.description: Chronic fatigue and recovery journeys reveal a persistent struggle with people-pleasing, overexertion, and difficulty attaining genuine rest. Participants actively work to retrain rest habits and set boundaries, both to protect emotional capacity and to support ongoing wellbeing. Coping tools and conscious behavioral changes bring stability and allow sustainable progress, enabling resilience through setbacks and daily challenges.

themes.name: Desperation, loss of agency, and willingness to radically change life for recovery
themes.description: The emotional extremes of desperation push participants to endure significant lifestyle changes, often motivated by diminished agency and devastating diagnoses. They pursue every possible avenue—from trying novel therapies to making abrupt modifications—to regain a sense of control and autonomy. These periods are marked by heightened vulnerability, reliance on others, grief, and loss, as participants struggle for hope amidst emotional turmoil.

themes.name: Discovering the mind-body connection and healing suppressed emotions as key to recovery
themes.description: Participants recognize that lasting recovery hinges on understanding and expressing emotions previously suppressed—especially anger, grief, and avoidance of conflict. Emotional processing is seen as vital, with therapy and specific practices helping bridge psychological and physical healing. The importance of integrated mind-body approaches, trauma healing, and spiritual work emerges as a turning point in recovery, challenging compartmentalized treatment.

themes.name: Reclaiming personal agency and finding empowerment through self-directed, skill-based healing
themes.description: A meaningful outcome for participants is the shift from passive medical dependence to active engagement with self-directed healing. Learning skills to regulate physiology, build emotional resilience, and challenge limiting beliefs fosters agency. By rejecting ‘quick fixes’ and symptom chasing, participants describe gaining confidence and empowerment that, together with supportive coaching and peer validation, enable sustainable recovery.

themes.name: Longing for genuine connection and community with others who share the journey
themes.description: The need for connection with peers who have faced similar health challenges emerges as a vital source of emotional support and validation. Participants value stories of recovery, community spaces, and supportive relationships that foster hope and resilience. Sharing experiences with and helping others, either through mutual support or coaching, becomes an important outcome and source of meaning after hardship.

themes.name: Embracing imperfection, joy, and appreciation for everyday life after recovery
themes.description: Following profound loss and transformation, participants describe a renewed sense of joy, gratitude, and wonder for everyday experiences. Acceptance of imperfection in health, self-compassion in setbacks, and a commitment to lifelong growth bring ongoing fulfillment. Stories reveal how reclaiming life, embracing spiritual and emotional growth, and celebrating ‘small wins’ are not only markers of recovery, but enduring sources of satisfaction.

themes.name: Managing emotional overwhelm and uncertainty in coping with unpredictable symptoms
themes.description: Participants experience persistent overwhelm, fear, and confusion due to the diversity and severity of chronic illness symptoms. This drives a quest for reassurance and hope, often through comparison with peers and searching for approaches matched to their unique needs. The process of learning to emotionally regulate through coping skills, personalized recovery plans, and acceptance of setbacks is central in handling distress and uncertainty.

report.output:
**Clinging to inner hope and refusing to accept illness as a permanent fate shapes every step of recovery**
Participants persistently maintained a belief in the possibility of improvement despite prolonged illness and repeated setbacks, describing hope as a "practical and emotional lifeline." This stubborn optimism fueled engagement with therapies, connection with others, and resilience in daily life. As one participant reflected, "I never ever felt in fact I was almost like in denial..." and another asserted, "You’re not going to tell me how I’m going to be for the rest of my life...". Success stories of fellow patients further inspired ongoing hope and efforts toward healing.

**Profound emotional isolation, loss, and longing for validation after misunderstood illness**
Many participants described deep emotional isolation and grief resulting from friends, family, and medical professionals minimizing or misunderstanding their illness, which increased the need for validation and occasional detachment. The struggle was illustrated by statements such as "Mustn't isolate yourself..." and "They never understood it then...". Emotional triggers from disbelief led to feelings of invisibility and distress, with one admitting, "I can flare up when people say silly things...".

**Radical transformation of identity and self-worth after losing achievements and confronting change**
Illness forced a shift away from achievement-based self-worth to greater self-acceptance and humility. Transformation involved listening to bodily signals and acknowledging personal limits, with participants revealing, "I've learnt to listen to myself..." and "It's been a journey of getting to know myself...". Fear of lost identity also emerged, yet for many, the process offered a deeper connection to intrinsic value and authenticity.

**Learning boundaries, self-care, and letting go of ingrained habits for lasting wellbeing**
Chronic fatigue and recovery reflected a constant struggle with overexertion, people-pleasing, and attaining genuine rest. Participants worked to retrain habits and establish boundaries to protect wellness, captured by, "I kept pushing myself..." and "The hardest for me was learning boundaries...". Intentionally prioritizing restful habits and disengaging from emotional triggers proved critical for stability and resilience.

**Desperation, loss of agency, and willingness to radically change life for recovery**
Periods of desperation spurred dramatic lifestyle changes, often in response to diminished agency and devastating diagnoses. Reliance on others and abrupt shifting of priorities were common, highlighting emotional vulnerability. One participant shared, "I had quite a support group..." and another noted, "When I had to start doing my own cooking...". Grief and loss marked a willingness to experiment widely to regain control and hope.

**Discovering the mind-body connection and healing suppressed emotions as key to recovery**
Lasting recovery was closely linked to expressing emotions previously suppressed, particularly anger and grief. Participants described how therapy and mind-body practices facilitated psychological and physical healing. Quotes such as "A lot of people with chronic fatigue are people pleasers..." and "I've learnt to listen to myself..." emphasized the process, with some realizing, "I actually smile and I say to myself...real rest..." and another recounting "Such a crazy mix of symptoms...can be overwhelming and confusing and scary...".

**Reclaiming personal agency and finding empowerment through self-directed, skill-based healing**
Participants described a pivotal shift from medical dependence to self-directed healing, building confidence, emotional regulation skills, and rejecting quick fixes. "I kept pushing myself..." and "I'm not good at resting..." illustrated these struggles, but ultimately, the adoption of new techniques and support networks enabled sustainable progress. Empowerment and connection with growth-minded peers played vital roles.

**Longing for genuine connection and community with others who share the journey**
The need to connect with others who share the chronic illness experience emerged as a cornerstone of emotional support and hope, making peer validation especially valuable. Many expressed, "Mustn't isolate yourself..." and "They never understood it then...", emphasizing the importance of shared understanding and helping others on similar paths.

**Embracing imperfection, joy, and appreciation for everyday life after recovery**
After periods of loss and transformation, participants reported newfound joy and gratitude for daily experiences, coupled with self-compassion through setbacks. "I had quite a support group..." and "I've learnt to listen to myself..." typified this acceptance, with life after recovery marked by ongoing spiritual and emotional growth.

**Managing emotional overwhelm and uncertainty in coping with unpredictable symptoms**
The diversity and severity of symptoms were described as confusing and overwhelming, prompting distress and increased efforts to seek reassurance. "Such a crazy mix of symptoms...can be overwhelming and confusing and scary..." and "I actually smile and I say to myself...real rest..." showcased ongoing struggles with uncertainty and the use of individualized coping strategies.
